propositions.text: An individual arrives at a house on a cold, snowy day.
The individual is described as wearing a dark coat, scarf, and hat pulled low.
The individual rings the doorbell, which sounds loudly in the basement.
The housekeeper, Mrs. Kale, expresses annoyance at the doorbell.
Mrs. Kale opens the door to find a man, who asks if she is Mrs. Lyon.
Mrs. Kale directs him to the third floor, questioning if he has an appointment.
The man shakes his head, and Mrs. Kale advises him to knock.
She observes him ascending the stairs, finding him 'ridiculous'.
She suspects he has a bad cold due to the weather.
As he reaches a landing, he begins to whistle 'Three Blind Mice'.
Molly Davis inspects the newly painted sign for 'Monksweir Guest House'.
She is satisfied with the sign, despite minor imperfections in the lettering.
She praises her husband, Giles, for his capability and foresight.
Molly and Giles are new to the guest house business.
The idea originated from Molly after inheriting Monksweir Manor from her Aunt Katherine.
Initially, they planned to sell the house and its Victorian furniture.
They faced difficulties finding a suitable smaller home and disposing of the bulky furniture.
A broker suggested the house could be sold as a hotel or guest house, including the furniture.
Molly proposed they open the guest house themselves.
She envisioned a manageable operation with few guests, self-sufficiency in food, and eventual employment of a maid.
Giles agreed, as they both desired a settled home.
Advertisements for guests were placed, and bookings started arriving.
The first guest is expected today.
Giles goes to buy wire netting, while Molly walks to the village.
The weather deteriorates into heavy snowfall.
Molly worries about frozen pipes and the potential for immediate misfortune.
She checks her watch and wonders if Giles has returned.
They have a private joke about canned goods, which they have stockpiled.
Molly returns to an empty house and feels a profound sense of loneliness.
She surveys the rooms prepared for guests: Mrs. Boyle, Major Metcalf, and Mr. Rance.
The sound of snow against the windows amplifies her unease.
While eating a hard biscuit and drinking tea, she contemplates the need for staff and feels her life is unreal, like an act.
A shadow at the window signals the approach of a stranger.
She hears the side door open and a stranger enters the hall, dusting off snow.
Her illusion of loneliness vanishes as she recognizes Giles.
Giles complains about the weather and being cold.
Molly hangs up his coat and empties his pockets, finding a scarf, newspaper, yarn, and mail.
She asks about the wire netting, and Giles confirms he couldn't find any.
They discuss the arrival of guests: Mrs. Boyle tomorrow, Major Metcalf and Mr. Rance today.
Major Metcalf's arrival is delayed until tomorrow.
They anticipate having dinner with Mr. Rance, with Giles suspecting he's a retired civil servant and Molly believing he's an artist.
Giles suggests Mr. Rance should pay a week's rent in advance, citing potential financial issues.
Molly proposes holding onto their luggage if they can't pay.
Giles expresses concern about their inexperience in running a guest house.
Molly anticipates Mrs. Boyle will notice their amateur status.
Molly prepares Welsh rarebit, explaining the ingredients.
Giles compliments her cooking skills.
Molly admits she can only manage one dish at a time and finds breakfast particularly challenging due to the timing of multiple items.
Giles jokingly offers to watch her make breakfast the next morning.
Molly announces the water is boiling and suggests listening to the radio in the study.
They discuss the possibility of having a radio in the kitchen.
Molly praises the kitchen, particularly the pantry, crockery, and large stove.
She contrasts the comfort of the old Victorian furniture with the problems of modern apartments.
They turn on the radio for the news.
The news reports bad weather, diplomatic impasses, parliamentary disputes, and a murder on Galois Street.
Molly expresses dismay at the news, particularly the fuel conservation appeals.
She wonders about the identity and motive for the murder of Mrs. Lyon.
Giles speculates about hidden treasure as a motive.
They discuss the police's focus on a person near the scene.
The doorbell rings again, startling them.
Giles jokingly suggests it's the murderer.
They anticipate it's Mr. Rance and speculate about their differing opinions of him.
Mr. Rance arrives, entering the house amidst the snow.
Molly observes him, noting the similarity of men in formal attire.
Giles closes the door, and Mr. Rance quickly removes his scarf, suitcase, and hat.
He speaks loudly, complaining about the harsh British winter.
He introduces himself to Molly, expressing surprise at her appearance.
He is fascinated by the idea of the house, associating it with Victorian grandeur.
He eagerly asks to see the 'beautiful china cupboards' made of mahogany.
Molly, overwhelmed by his rapid speech, confirms they have them.
He insists on seeing them immediately and enters the dining room.
He examines the large food cupboard and then criticizes the lack of a large mahogany dining table.
He describes a typical large Victorian family setting.
Giles offers to take Mr. Rance's suitcase upstairs to the East room.
Mr. Rance asks about the beds, specifically those with four-poster frames and carved roses.
He inquires about Giles's past and asks if Molly loves him.
Molly steers the conversation to his room.
Mr. Rance confesses his real name is Christopher Rance and that his parents wanted him to be an architect.
He claims to be a (nearly) qualified architect and designs prefabricated houses.
Giles returns downstairs, and Molly leads Mr. Rance to his room.
Giles expresses his displeasure with Mr. Rance.
Molly explains she switched rooms for Mr. Rance because he desired a four-poster bed.
Giles mutters an insult about Mr. Rance.
Molly reminds Giles they are running a guest house and should focus on payment.
Mr. Rance agrees to pay seven guineas a week.
Giles suspects Mr. Rance's suitcase is light, possibly filled with stones.
Molly warns Giles that Mr. Rance is approaching.
Christopher Rance is shown to the study and is told dinner will be in half an hour.
He offers to help cook, suggesting he can make scrambled eggs.
Christopher helps in the kitchen.
Molly feels uneasy about the opening day, but hopes for improvement when other guests arrive.
The next morning, snow continues to fall, and both Giles and Molly are in low spirits.
Mrs. Boyle arrives by car with snow chains, accompanied by a driver who describes the worsening conditions.
Mrs. Boyle is an imposing woman with a loud and commanding voice, intensified by her military service.
She states she would not have come if she didn't believe the guest house was scientifically managed.
Giles suggests she leave if she's unsatisfied, emphasizing they have many potential guests.
Mrs. Boyle demands a larger bath towel, stating she's unaccustomed to drying herself with a handkerchief.
Giles makes a dismissive gesture to Molly after Mrs. Boyle leaves.
Molly tells Giles he can handle Mrs. Boyle.
Giles believes in showing such people who is in charge.
Molly wonders how Mrs. Boyle will get along with Christopher Rance.
Giles predicts they won't get along.
Later that afternoon, Mrs. Boyle makes critical remarks about Mr. Rance to Molly.
The bread delivery man arrives, warning that future deliveries may be delayed due to the snow.
He inquires about their provisions, and Molly mentions their stock of canned goods and a need for flour.
She considers making soda bread if bread delivery becomes impossible.
The newspaper reports on the weather and the Lyon murder case.
As Molly examines a photo of the victim, Christopher Rance comments on the murder, calling the victim 'slovenly' and the street 'squalid'.
Mrs. Boyle interjects that the victim deserved it.
Rance then questions if it was a crime of passion.
He probes Mrs. Boyle about what it feels like to strangle someone.
Molly reads a description of a suspect wanted by the police.
Rance notes that many people could fit the description.
At Scotland Yard, Inspector Parnham is meeting with Detective Inspector Cain and two workmen.
Parnham questions the workmen about the Lyon case.
The workmen, Joe and Bill, explain they needed matches and asked a passerby.
The passerby, who was heavily bundled up, gave them matches without speaking much.
He quickly left, dropping a small notebook.
The workmen attempted to return the notebook, but the man ran off.
They describe him as resembling a thief, with his hat pulled low and coat buttoned up.
Upon examining the notebook, they found two addresses: 74 Galois Street and Monksweir Manor.
At the top of one page, they found the inscription: 'Three blind mice must be got rid of, the knocker.'
Immediately after, they heard a woman scream 'Murder!' nearby.
Bill returned to find a crowd, police, and a murdered woman, identified as the landlady.
They came to the police because the address on the notebook matched the murder scene.
Parnham confirms the description of the suspect from the workmen and the landlady.
Parnham examines the notebook and a piece of paper found on the victim.
The note reads 'This is the first.' and includes a drawing of three mice and musical notation.
Cain recognizes the melody of 'Three Blind Mice'.
The victim is identified as Maureen Gregg, recently released from Holloway Prison.
Parnham infers the murder was premeditated and connected to Monksweir Manor.
Cain finds an advertisement for Monksweir Manor in an old newspaper.
The advertisement reveals Monksweir Manor is located in Hamptleford, Berkshire.
Parnham instructs Cain to contact the Berkshire police.
Major Metcalf arrives at Monksweir Manor, described as a respectable and pleasant middle-aged man.
He is satisfied with his room and furnishings.
He has connections with Mrs. Boyle's relatives.
Giles is reassured by the weight of Major Metcalf's luggage.
Molly and Giles are busy with the guest house operations, finding them satisfactory.
They are awakened at 2 AM by the doorbell.
Giles, in his pajamas, goes to answer the door.
Molly, curious, watches from the stairs as Giles helps a bearded stranger remove his snowy coat.
The stranger complains of cold fingers and feet.
Giles offers him the study to wait while a room is prepared.
The stranger, M. Balavichi, considers himself lucky.
Molly observes him as an older man with a small beard and Mephistophelean eyebrows, moving nimbly.
Giles explains the guest's car overturned in the snow and he found their sign.
He assures Molly it's unlikely to be a thief on such a night.
He identifies the guest as a foreigner named Balavichi, whose wallet was full of money.
They decide to give him the green room, which needs only bed-making.
They agree to lend him pajamas as his belongings are in the car.
Giles worries they will be completely cut off by the snow.
Molly expresses concern about making soda bread without prior experience.
They anticipate disruptions to deliveries, newspapers, and possibly the telephone.
They discuss the need for their own electricity and sufficient heating fuel.
Molly feels they are facing a difficult time and asks Giles to fetch Balavichi.
The morning reveals five feet of snow, isolating the house.
Mrs. Boyle is eating breakfast alone, while Major Metcalf has finished.
Mr. Rance's breakfast remains untouched.
Mrs. Boyle is dissatisfied with Monksweir Manor, having expected opportunities to display her social standing.
The end of the war has left her feeling displaced and lacking purpose.
She criticizes the establishment for not informing her that the guest house was newly opened.
The quality of the food and comfort of the bed leave her with no valid excuses to complain.
She observes Mr. Rance, finding him 'odd' and his gaze 'unsettling'.
She feels the lukewarm radiator and declares she cannot stay.
Mr. Rance appears, amused, and tells her she won't be leaving.
Major Metcalf is helping Giles shovel snow from the back door.
Major Metcalf emphasizes the importance of daily exercise.
He praises Molly's thoughtfulness in preparing his breakfast.
Giles notes the Major's early rising and apparent surplus of energy.
He wonders about the Major's reasons for being at Monksweir.
Balavichi comes down for a continental breakfast of coffee and toast.
He makes an overly elaborate bow to Molly, making her uncomfortable.
Molly feels flustered by the irregular breakfast times.
She goes upstairs to make beds, as Giles is busy clearing paths to the boiler room and chicken coop.
The telephone rings while she is in the bathroom.
She is relieved the phone is working and answers it.
The caller is Sergeant Hogben from Berkshire Police, who states he has sent Detective Inspector Trotter.
Molly explains they are snowbound and cannot receive visitors.
Hogben assures her Trotter will arrive and instructs her to have her husband follow his instructions.
The call is abruptly ended.
Giles enters, covered in snow and soot, and asks Molly what's wrong.
Molly informs him about the call from the police.
Giles expresses suspicion about why the police would be involved.
They speculate about potential legal issues related to their business, like the butter or the radio license.
Giles mentions a near-accident caused by another driver.
Molly becomes distressed, convinced they've done something wrong.
Giles laments that in the current times, almost anything can be illegal, and running a guest house may lead to unforeseen problems.
They consider alcohol as a potential issue, but haven't served it yet.

concepts.name: Weather
concepts.context: The story begins with a description of cold and impending snow. Snowfall is a recurring element, impacting travel, creating isolation, and influencing the mood of characters. Specific mentions include 'cold', 'snowy day', 'falling snow', 'heavy snow', 'frozen pipes', 'snow drifts', 'snowbound', 'snow chains', 'snow-covered', 'snowfall', 'blinding snow', 'snowing'.

concepts.name: Guest House
concepts.context: The central setting and plot revolve around the opening and operation of a guest house called 'Monksweir Guest House'. Characters discuss its establishment, the challenges of running it, guest arrivals, and its management. Key terms include 'guest house', 'hotel', 'boarding house', 'hostel', 'manor', 'apartment', 'rooms', 'guests'.

concepts.name: Characters
concepts.context: Numerous characters are introduced, including the owners (Molly and Giles Davis), guests (Mrs. Boyle, Major Metcalf, Mr. Rance/Christopher Rance, M. Balavichi), staff (Mrs. Kale, bread delivery man), and police (Inspector Parnham, Detective Inspector Cain, Sergeant Hogben, Detective Inspector Trotter). Descriptions of their personalities and interactions are frequent.

concepts.name: Murder
concepts.context: The murder of Mrs. Lyon on Galois Street is a significant plot point, initially reported on the radio and later discussed by guests and police. The investigation and potential connection to Monksweir are explored. Terms include 'murder', 'killed', 'victim', 'homicide', 'suspect', 'police'.

concepts.name: Mystery
concepts.context: Elements of mystery pervade the narrative, including the identity of the initial visitor, the motivation for the murder, the suspicious behavior of some guests, and the police investigation. The 'Three Blind Mice' motif adds a cryptic layer.

concepts.name: Victorian Era
concepts.context: The story references the Victorian era, particularly in relation to the inherited furniture and the perceived style of Monksweir Manor. Characters discuss the comfort and grandeur of Victorian items.

concepts.name: Scotland Yard
concepts.context: The police investigation into the murder takes place at Scotland Yard, involving Inspector Parnham and Detective Inspector Cain, highlighting the official response to the crime.

concepts.name: Monksweir Manor
concepts.context: This is the inherited property that becomes the location of the Monksweir Guest House. It is described as a large, old house with Victorian furniture. It is also a key address in the murder investigation.

concepts.name: Three Blind Mice
concepts.context: This nursery rhyme is a recurring motif, first whistled by the mysterious visitor and later appearing in a note related to the murder. It serves as a potential clue or signature.

concepts.name: Isolation
concepts.context: The heavy snowfall leads to the isolation of Monksweir, cutting off communication and making escape impossible, thus intensifying the potential for mystery and danger.

concepts.name: Inexperience
concepts.context: Molly and Giles's inexperience in running a guest house is a recurring concern, impacting their confidence and their interactions with guests and the police.

concepts.name: Luggage
concepts.context: Luggage is mentioned in relation to guests' arrivals and departures, and Giles expresses suspicion about the lightness of Mr. Rance's suitcase.

concepts.name: Addresses
concepts.context: Specific addresses, such as 74 Galois Street and Monksweir Manor, are crucial to the police investigation, linking the murder to the guest house.

concepts.name: Newspaper
concepts.context: Newspapers are a source of information about the murder and also play a role in the discovery of Monksweir's advertisement.

concepts.name: Food
concepts.context: Food preparation, such as Welsh rarebit and breakfast, is described, highlighting the domestic aspects of the guest house and Molly's efforts.

concepts.name: Telephone
concepts.context: The telephone is a vital means of communication, particularly when the house is snowbound. The call from the police highlights its importance.

concepts.name: Radio
concepts.context: The radio provides news, including reports of the weather and the murder, and is seen as a potential connection to the outside world.

concepts.name: Motive
concepts.context: The characters speculate about the motive for the murder, considering treasure or a crime of passion.

concepts.name: Crime
concepts.context: The narrative involves criminal activity, primarily the murder and the subsequent police investigation. The idea of illegality in current times is also a theme.

concepts.name: Accident
concepts.context: The overturned car of M. Balavichi and Giles's near-accident highlight the dangers and uncertainties of travel, especially in adverse weather.

concepts.name: Music
concepts.context: The 'Three Blind Mice' melody appears as a musical clue, linking the murder to the rhyme.

concepts.name: Fear
concepts.context: Characters experience fear and unease due to the weather, the murder, and the arrival of suspicious individuals.

concepts.name: Money
concepts.context: Financial matters are discussed, including the potential for guests to pay rent and the value of Balavichi's money.

concepts.name: Identity
concepts.context: The theme of hidden identities is present, with Maureen Gregg using an alias, and the mystery surrounding the true nature of some guests.

concepts.name: Victorian Furniture
concepts.context: The old, bulky Victorian furniture is a defining characteristic of Monksweir Manor and is contrasted with modern, less functional furniture.

concepts.name: Police
concepts.context: The police, represented by Scotland Yard and Berkshire Police, are actively investigating the murder, adding a layer of suspense and official inquiry to the narrative.

concepts.name: Observation
concepts.context: Characters constantly observe each other, their surroundings, and the unfolding events, forming opinions and seeking clues.

concepts.name: Conversation
concepts.context: Much of the narrative unfolds through dialogue, revealing character motivations, plot points, and building suspense.

concepts.name: Housekeeper
concepts.context: Mrs. Kale is briefly introduced as the housekeeper who dislikes the doorbell.

concepts.name: Sign
concepts.context: The newly painted sign for Monksweir Guest House is inspected by Molly.

concepts.name: Inheritance
concepts.context: Molly inherits Monksweir Manor from her aunt, which initiates the events of the story.

concepts.name: Broker
concepts.context: A broker suggests selling the property as a guest house.

concepts.name: Advertising
concepts.context: Advertisements are placed to attract guests to the new guest house.

concepts.name: Canned goods
concepts.context: A private joke between Molly and Giles, they have a large stock of canned goods.

concepts.name: Loneliness
concepts.context: Molly experiences a profound sense of loneliness when she is alone in the house.

concepts.name: Illusion
concepts.context: Molly's illusion of loneliness vanishes when Giles returns.

concepts.name: Mail
concepts.context: Molly finds mail in Giles's pocket.

concepts.name: Wire netting
concepts.context: Giles goes to buy wire netting but is unsuccessful.

concepts.name: Postcard
concepts.context: Major Metcalf sends a postcard to inform them of his delayed arrival.

concepts.name: Artist
concepts.context: Molly believes Mr. Rance is an artist.

concepts.name: Civil servant
concepts.context: Giles suspects Mr. Rance is a retired civil servant.

concepts.name: Rent
concepts.context: The concept of paying rent is discussed in relation to the guests.

concepts.name: Luggage
concepts.context: Giles suspects Mr. Rance's suitcase is light and possibly filled with stones.

concepts.name: Welsh rarebit
concepts.context: Molly prepares Welsh rarebit.

concepts.name: Master chef
concepts.context: Giles praises Molly's cooking.

concepts.name: Breakfast
concepts.context: Breakfast is described as a challenging meal to prepare due to its timing.

concepts.name: Pantry
concepts.context: Molly likes the pantry in the kitchen.

concepts.name: Crockery
concepts.context: Molly likes the crockery in the kitchen.

concepts.name: Stove
concepts.context: Molly likes the large stove in the kitchen.

concepts.name: Fuel
concepts.context: Discussions about fuel for heating arise.

concepts.name: Modern apartments
concepts.context: Molly contrasts the old furniture with the problems of modern apartments.

concepts.name: News
concepts.context: News reports on bad weather, diplomacy, parliament, and a murder.

concepts.name: Diplomacy
concepts.context: Diplomatic impasses are mentioned in the news.

concepts.name: Parliament
concepts.context: Parliamentary disputes are mentioned in the news.

concepts.name: Galois Street
concepts.context: This street is mentioned as the location of the murder and is a key address for the police.

concepts.name: Treasure
concepts.context: Giles speculates about treasure as a motive for the murder.

concepts.name: Appearance
concepts.context: Descriptions of characters' appearances are frequent, including clothing, physical features, and general demeanor.

concepts.name: Suitcase
concepts.context: Suitcases are mentioned in relation to guests' belongings.

concepts.name: Hat
concepts.context: The suspect in the murder is described as wearing a hat pulled low.

concepts.name: Scarf
concepts.context: Scarves are part of the suspect's description.

concepts.name: Victorian grandeur
concepts.context: Mr. Rance associates the house with Victorian grandeur.

concepts.name: Cupboards
concepts.context: Mr. Rance is eager to see the china cupboards.

concepts.name: Mahogany
concepts.context: The cupboards and dining table are described as mahogany.

concepts.name: Dining room
concepts.context: Mr. Rance enters the dining room.

concepts.name: Food cupboard
concepts.context: Mr. Rance examines the large food cupboard.

concepts.name: Dining table
concepts.context: Mr. Rance laments the lack of a large dining table.

concepts.name: Family
concepts.context: Mr. Rance describes a typical Victorian family.

concepts.name: East room
concepts.context: Giles takes Mr. Rance's suitcase to the East room.

concepts.name: Bed
concepts.context: Mr. Rance is particular about the beds, wanting a four-poster.

concepts.name: Roses
concepts.context: Carved roses are mentioned on the four-poster beds.

concepts.name: Navy
concepts.context: Giles served in the Navy.

concepts.name: Army
concepts.context: Mentioned in contrast to the Navy.

concepts.name: Air Force
concepts.context: Mentioned in contrast to the Navy.

concepts.name: Marriage
concepts.context: Mr. Rance asks about Molly and Giles's marriage length and love.

concepts.name: Feelings
concepts.context: Mr. Rance expresses interest in understanding people's feelings and thoughts.

concepts.name: Emotions
concepts.context: Mr. Rance expresses interest in understanding people's feelings and thoughts.

concepts.name: Thoughts
concepts.context: Mr. Rance expresses interest in understanding people's feelings and thoughts.

concepts.name: Christopher Rance
concepts.context: Mr. Rance's real name and profession (architect) are revealed.

concepts.name: Architect
concepts.context: Christopher Rance's intended profession and current (partial) profession.

concepts.name: Prefabricated houses
concepts.context: Christopher Rance designs prefabricated houses.

concepts.name: Prepayment
concepts.context: Giles suggests Mr. Rance pay a week's rent in advance.

concepts.name: Hold luggage
concepts.context: Molly suggests holding luggage if guests cannot pay.

concepts.name: Stones
concepts.context: Giles jokingly suspects Mr. Rance's suitcase is full of stones.

concepts.name: Mischief
concepts.context: Giles mutters an insult about Mr. Rance.

concepts.name: Guineas
concepts.context: The price of seven guineas per week is mentioned.

concepts.name: Evidence
concepts.context: Molly states Mr. Rance's agreement to pay is in writing.

concepts.name: Study
concepts.context: The study is where Mr. Rance waits and later has dinner.

concepts.name: Scrambled eggs
concepts.context: Mr. Rance offers to cook scrambled eggs.

concepts.name: Opening day
concepts.context: Molly feels uneasy about the opening day of the guest house.

concepts.name: Low spirits
concepts.context: Molly and Giles are in low spirits due to the weather.

concepts.name: Snow chains
concepts.context: Mrs. Boyle's car has snow chains.

concepts.name: Road conditions
concepts.context: The driver describes the terrible road conditions.

concepts.name: Domineering voice
concepts.context: Mrs. Boyle has a loud, domineering voice.

concepts.name: Military service
concepts.context: Mrs. Boyle's military service intensified her personality, and Major Metcalf also has military bearing.

concepts.name: Scientific management
concepts.context: Mrs. Boyle believes the guest house is scientifically managed.

concepts.name: Future rent
concepts.context: Giles mentions they will raise rents in the future.

concepts.name: Bath towel
concepts.context: Mrs. Boyle asks for a larger bath towel.

concepts.name: Handkerchief
concepts.context: Mrs. Boyle is not accustomed to drying herself with a handkerchief.

concepts.name: Dismissive gesture
concepts.context: Giles makes a dismissive gesture to Molly.

concepts.name: Taste of their own medicine
concepts.context: Giles believes in giving difficult people a taste of their own medicine.

concepts.name: Criticism
concepts.context: Mrs. Boyle criticizes Mr. Rance to Molly.

concepts.name: Bread delivery
concepts.context: The bread delivery is threatened by the snow, prompting Molly to consider baking her own.

concepts.name: Provisions
concepts.context: The bread delivery man asks about their provisions.

concepts.name: Flour
concepts.context: Molly mentions a need for more flour.

concepts.name: Irish soda bread
concepts.context: Molly considers making Irish soda bread.

concepts.name: Foreign affairs
concepts.context: Foreign affairs are no longer the focus of the news.

concepts.name: Victim's photograph
concepts.context: Molly gazes at the photograph of the murder victim.

concepts.name: Ghastly murder
concepts.context: Rance describes the murder as ghastly.

concepts.name: Slovenly victim
concepts.context: Rance calls the victim slovenly.

concepts.name: Squalid street
concepts.context: Rance calls the street squalid.

concepts.name: Crime of passion
concepts.context: Rance asks if the murder was a crime of passion.

concepts.name: Strangling
concepts.context: Rance probes Mrs. Boyle about the feeling of strangling someone.

concepts.name: Really, Mr. Rance!
concepts.context: Mrs. Boyle's repeated exclamation of disbelief.

concepts.name: Description of suspect
concepts.context: Molly reads the police description of the murder suspect.

concepts.name: Scotland Yard
concepts.context: The police investigation headquarters.

concepts.name: Inspector Parnham
concepts.context: The lead inspector at Scotland Yard.

concepts.name: Detective Chief Inspector Cain
concepts.context: Cain assists Inspector Parnham.

concepts.name: Workmen
concepts.context: Joe and Bill, the workmen who found the notebook and heard the scream.

concepts.name: Decent, slow, reliable men
concepts.context: Description of the workmen by Cain.

concepts.name: Uneasy
concepts.context: The workmen look uneasy when brought before Parnham.

concepts.name: Lyon case
concepts.context: The murder case being investigated.

concepts.name: Cigarettes
concepts.context: Parnham offers cigarettes to the workmen.

concepts.name: Gas main
concepts.context: The location where the workmen were working.

concepts.name: Garmon Street
concepts.context: The street where the workmen were.

concepts.name: Passerby
concepts.context: The unidentified man who gave the workmen matches and dropped the notebook.

concepts.name: Whisper
concepts.context: The passerby replies in a whisper.

concepts.name: Fleeing hare
concepts.context: Bill compares the passerby's speed to a fleeing hare.

concepts.name: Harrow Road
concepts.context: The street the passerby ran into.

concepts.name: Thief in a picture
concepts.context: The workmen describe the passerby's appearance as resembling a thief.

concepts.name: Notebook
concepts.context: The dropped notebook contains crucial information for the investigation.

concepts.name: Addresses
concepts.context: The notebook contains two important addresses.

concepts.name: Monksweir Hall
concepts.context: Bill corrects the name of the manor to Hall.

concepts.name: Knocker
concepts.context: Part of the inscription in the notebook.

concepts.name: Scream
concepts.context: The workmen heard a woman scream 'Murder!'.

concepts.name: Throat cut
concepts.context: Bill reports the victim had her throat cut.

concepts.name: Landlady
concepts.context: The victim was the landlady.

concepts.name: Relevance
concepts.context: The workmen discussed the relevance of the notebook to the murder.

concepts.name: Leaving the house
concepts.context: The police were looking for someone leaving the murder scene.

concepts.name: Note on victim
concepts.context: A note was found on the victim.

concepts.name: Musical notation
concepts.context: Included on the note found with the victim.

concepts.name: Maureen Gregg
concepts.context: The victim's real name.

concepts.name: Holloway Prison
concepts.context: Maureen Gregg was released from here.

concepts.name: Premeditated
concepts.context: Parnham believes the murder was premeditated.

concepts.name: Advertisement
concepts.context: An advertisement for Monksweir Manor is found in a newspaper.

concepts.name: Hamptleford, Berkshire
concepts.context: The location of Monksweir Manor.

concepts.text: 'Who is it?'
Giles makes a wry face: 'Another guest for the hotel. The car overturned in a snowdrift. He got out of the car and tried to find his way. Listen to the wind and snow howling.'
'He says the sign seemed like an answer to his prayers.'
'You don't think he's dangerous?'
'My dear, on a night like this, thieves don't go out.'
'He's a foreigner, isn't he?'
'Yes. His name is Balavichi. I saw his walletor rather, he deliberately showed it to me. It was bulging with banknotes.'
'Which room shall we give him?'
'The green one. It's ready. Just needs the bed made.'
'I suppose we must lend him pajamas? His things are in the car. He said he had to climb out of the window.'
Molly fetches sheets, pillowcases, and towels.
While they make the bed, Giles says, 'It's snowing harder. Molly, we're going to be snowed in, completely cut off. It's rather worrying, isn't it?'
'I don't know,' Molly says doubtfully. 'Giles, can I really make soda bread?'
'Of course, you can. You can do anything.' Her devoted husband says.
'I've never tried making bread. It's assumed everyone can do it. Fresh or not, the baker brings it. But if the snow blocks the roads, the baker won't come!'
'Nor the butcher, nor the postman. We won't get the papers. Perhaps the telephone will be out of order.'
'Only the wireless will tell us everything.'
'We must generate our own electricity anyway.'
'You'll have to start the engine again tomorrow. And we must lay in a stock of fuel for the heating.'
'I don't suppose the next delivery of coke will arrive now. We've very little left!'
'Oh, bother. Giles, I think we've landed ourselves in a fearful mess. Go and fetch Balavichiwhatever his name is. I'm going back to bed.'
The morning confirms Giles's prediction: five feet of snow, blocking doors and windows.
Outside, it continues to snow, and the world is a blank, silent expanse that feels vaguely threatening.
Mrs. Boyle is eating breakfast, alone in the dining room.
Major Metcalf has already finished his breakfast and tidied up at an adjacent table.
Mr. Rance's breakfast is still on his table, waiting for him.
He rose early but is too late for breakfast.
Mrs. Boyle knows that the correct time for breakfast is nine o'clock.
Having finished her delicious scrambled eggs and chewing her toast with strong white teeth, Mrs. Boyle is neither pleased nor knows what to do.
Monksweir Guest House is not at all what she had imagined.
She had hoped to play bridge, to meet some old maids, to show them her social position and connections, and even hint at her status and secrets from her army days.
The end of the war seemed to have banished Mrs. Boyle to a desolate beach.
She had been a busy woman, always talking of efficiency and organisation.
Her energy and drive made one hesitate to ask if she herself was a good or efficient organiser.
The war activities suited her perfectly. She was overbearing and bullying; she worried the department heads; she was extremely strict with herself.
The women under her were at her beck and call; a frown from her could make them tremble.
But now that busy life was over.
She had returned to her private life, and that private life had vanished.

Her house had been commandeered by the army, and would require complete renovation and redecoration before she could move in, and it was impractical to move in at present owing to lack of domestic staff.
Old friends had disappeared.
At present, she needed a place to stay, and the current situation was difficult for her.
A hotel or a boarding house was a solution.
So she had chosen Monksweir Guest House.
She glanced contemptuously around her.
'The most dishonest thing they did was not to tell me that this boarding house was newly opened,' she muttered to herself.
She pushed her plate away.
The breakfast made for her was excellent, the coffee was good, and the homemade jamstrangely enoughannoyed her.
It deprived her of any just excuse for complaining.
Her bed was very comfortable, with embroidered sheets and soft pillows.
Mrs. Boyle liked comfort, but she also liked to find fault.
Perhaps she liked finding fault more than comfort.
Mrs. Boyle rose with great solemnity and left the dining room, walking past the door of the conceited young man.
He was wearing a green tartan tie that morning.
'Odd,' she muttered to herself. 'Most odd.'
Mr. Rance's sidelong glance with his pale eyes at Mrs. Boyle's airs also displeased her.
There was something unsettling, something peculiar, in that slightly mocking glance.
'Quite mad,' she muttered to herself.
She nodded slightly in return for his mock bow and swept into the drawing-room.
The chairs here were very soft and comfortable, especially the large rose-colored one.
To show that the chair was occupied and reserved for her, she placed her knitting upon it and then went to the radiator and held out a hand.
As she had guessed, the radiator was warm, but not hot.
Mrs. Boyle's eyes flashed with a pugnacious light.
She could discourse on this matter with great authority.
She looked out of the window.
'Nasty weather, hateful weather!'
'Well,' she declared, 'I shall not stay here long unless some more guests arrive to make the boarding house interesting.'
Snow was falling softly from the roof to the ground.
Mrs. Boyle sprang up and exclaimed loudly, 'No, I cannot stay here any longer.'
Someone was laughing, a low, suppressed laugh.
She turned suddenly and saw the young Rance standing in the doorway, looking at her with curiosity.
'No,' he said. 'I don't think you will.'
Major Metcalf was helping Giles shovel the snow from the back door.
He did it admirably, and Giles thanked him heartily.
'It's excellent exercise,' said Major Metcalf. 'One must keep oneself in condition, you know.'
The Major was an enthusiast for exercise.
Giles feared him for this, as he required breakfast at half-past seven.
The Major seemed to read Giles's thoughts and said, 'Your wife was very thoughtful in making me breakfast so early. Fresh eggs are quite delightful.'
As a result of the needs of the hotel business, Giles rose at seven o'clock.
He and Molly prepared and took the eggs and tea to the sitting-room.
Everything was done neatly and tidily.
Giles could not help thinking that if he were a guest in his own hotel, on a morning like this, nothing short of absolute necessity could drag him out of bed.
But the Major was up and had already had his breakfast.
He was pacing about the room, clearly overflowing with energy and wanting to expend it.
'Well,' thought Giles. 'There's plenty of snow to shovel.'
He glanced sideways at his companion.
It was not an easy man to manage, this man who had seen service in the war; he was middle-aged, and his eyes showed a peculiar alertness, missing nothing.
Giles did not understand what he had come to Monksweir Manor for.
Was he demobilized, or could he not find work?
Balavichi came downstairs late.
Coffee and a piece of toast constituted his European breakfast.
When Molly took him his breakfast, he rose and made an excessively theatrical bow, exclaiming loudly, 'Everything is satisfactory, my charming hostess, is it not?'
This made Molly rather uncomfortable.
Molly could only answer vaguely, 'Very well.'
At such times, she had no inclination for pleasantries.
'Oh, dear!' Molly said carelessly, pushing plates and cups into the sink.
'Serving breakfast at such odd hours is very trying!'
After putting the dishes in the rack, she hurried upstairs to make the beds.
She could not expect Giles to help her this morning; he had to clear a path to the boiler room and the chicken run.
Molly made the beds quickly and carelessly, smoothing them down as fast as possible.
The telephone rang while she was in the bathroom.
Molly first cursed the telephone for disturbing her, then felt slightly reassured that at least it was still working.
She ran downstairs to answer it.
She reached the study slightly out of breath and took the receiver.
'Who is it?'
A voice with a slight country accent asked kindly, 'Is that Monksweir Guest House?'
'Yes, it is Monksweir Guest House and Boarding Establishment.'
'May I speak to Mr. Davis?'
'He may not be available at the moment!' Molly said. 'I am Mrs. Davis. Who is speaking?'
'Sergeant Hogben, Berkshire Police.'
Molly gave a small sigh.
'Oh, is that so? Is it?'
'Mrs. Davis, there is something very urgent. It is not convenient to discuss it over the telephone. I have dispatched Detective Inspector Trotter to your house, and he should arrive at any moment.'
'But he cannot come. We are snowbound. Completely snowbound. The roads are all blocked.'
The reply was confident.
'No difficulty whatever, Mrs. Davis. Trotter will get to you. Tell your husband to listen very carefully to Trotter's instructions and to act upon them. That is all.'
'But, Sergeant Hogben, what'
The receiver clicked as Hogben finished speaking and hung up.
Molly jiggled the receiver once or twice, got no response, and put it down.
The door opened, and she turned around.
'Oh, Giles, darling, is that you?'
Giles had snow in his hair and soot on his face.
He looked hot and sweated.
'What is it, darling? I've filled the coal scuttle and brought in the wood. I'll go and see to the hen-house, and then the boiler, shall I? What is it, Molly? You look as if you'd seen a ghost.'
'Giles, it was the police.'
'The police?' Giles said, his voice full of suspicion.
'Yes. They sent a sergeant or a detective-inspector or something.'
'Why? What have we done wrong?'
'I don't know. Do you think it's because we brought in two pounds of butter from Ireland?'
Giles frowned.
'I remember we took out a license for the wireless, didn't we?'

'Yes, on the desk. Giles, Mrs. Peterlock gave me five bonds for my tweed coat. I don't think I should have done that, but I thought it was perfectly fairI exchanged the coat for bonds. Oh, darling, what else?'
'I nearly had a motor accident the other day, but it was entirely the other fellow's fault; I wasn't to blame.'
'We must have done something wrong,' Molly sobbed.

'The trouble is that nowadays one can do anything wrong,' Giles said gloomily. 'That's why people often have a sense of guilt. Honestly, I think it has something to do with this place. Running a boarding house, you see, might lead to unexpected obstacles that we've never heard of.'
'I think alcohol is the only thing that could cause trouble. But we haven't served it to them, so why shouldn't we run our boarding house as we like?'
'I know. It sounds all right. But, as I said, at this time of day, everything is more or less forbidden.'

relations.target: Active participation in guest house tasks

main_topics: The First Guest and Early Concerns
hierarchy.structure: The document is structured chronologically, beginning with the arrival of the first mysterious visitor, then detailing the establishment and opening of Monksweir Guest House. The narrative progresses through the interactions with initial guests, the unfolding of the murder investigation, the impact of a severe snowstorm that isolates the house, and culminates in direct police involvement. Each section builds upon the previous, introducing new characters and plot developments that converge towards a central mystery.
